title: Meet Newcastle’s hair cutting entrepreneur
text:
Source: FOX SPORTS FROM cutting up the field to cutting hair — Newcastle hooker Danny Levi is one motivated man. 
An angry young rake on the field, Levi is a pocket-rocket cut out of the Issac Luke mould but you’ve never seen him like this. 
Unlike most 21-year-olds, Levi is somewhat of an entrepreneur. 
While his career on the paddock is flourishing, the 21-year-old is proof you’re never too young to start thinking about life after football. 
Having moved to Newcastle from Wellington, New Zealand in 2013 at the age of 17, Levi’s frustration at paying for overpriced barbers has transformed into a promising side career. 
Playing Holden Cup and looking to save some cash, Levi has gone from cutting his own hair to one of the most in-demand barbers in the Hunter. Danny Levi of the Knights looks to pass the ball. Source: Getty Images 
“I’ve always liked doing my hair but when I came over to Australia I was looking for a barber and when I found one, the prices were always pretty high,” Levi told foxsports.com.au. 
“I went to Kmart and bought myself a cheap pair of clippers and started to do my own hair.

“I enjoyed it so I started doing a few of the boys. The Saifiti (brothers) were the first two I practised on. I gave them some shocking haircuts at the start. But I got better in time. 
“Now I’ve got myself a nice pair of clippers.” 
A Junior Kiwis representative, Levi made his NRL debut in 2015. A post shared by Mickey Paea (@mickey_paea) on Jan 12, 2017 at 11:08pm PST 
Tipped as one of the players set to have a bright future at the Knights, Levi will add to his 25 games when he starts in the No.9 against the Warriors this weekend. 
While rugby league is his focus, he’s seen several of his teammates’ careers come to a sudden end almost overnight in recent seasons. 
It’s a reminder how quickly the dream can be over and why forward thinking is so important. 
“It is important to have something outside of footy,” he explained. 
“It’s something I’d definitely like to pursue when I finish footy or even during it. It’s something I enjoy. 
“I was watching the barber cut my hair and picking up tips. A post shared by Cut To The point (@cuttothepointdl) on Feb 10, 2017 at 7:28pm PST 
“I’d practise on myself and then at the start of last year I started cutting the boys’ hair. I convinced them by telling them how good I was so (the Saifiti brothers) gave me a chance. Now I’ve got most of the team coming around asking for haircuts.” 
Not only is Levi cutting hair but he’s doing what barbers do best — chatting with his clients. 
And fans have the chance to listen to the barbershop chatter in Levi’s podcast ‘ Cut To The Point ’ which can be found on SoundCloud. Danny Levi at training. Source: News Corp Australia 
Armed with a pair of scissors in hand and a microphone on the table, there’s no splitting of hairs when it comes to conversation on this podcast. 
“It wasn’t my idea,” he admitted. 
“My partner (Kimberley Goodearl) and brother-in-law (David Kosega) wanted to help me get some exposure. I was cutting my nephew’s hair and they came up with an idea of a podcast while I cut the boys’ hair. 
“I thought that was an awesome idea and pretty unique. They came up with the name and logo so it was my job to cut the boys’ hair and have a chat with them.
